coredata.dc:title: Polymer nanofibers framework composite solid electrolyte with lithium dendrite suppression for long life all-solid-state lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Li, Yuhan
Fu, Zhenyu
Lu, Shiyao
Sun, Xue
Zhang, Xiaorui
Weng, Ling
coredata.dc:description: The widespread deployment of lithium metal battery is limited by inhomogeneous electrodeposition of lithium metal (the growth of lithium dendrite), leading to pulverization, “dead” lithium and the unrestricted volume expansion of lithium metal anode. Owing to the high elastic modulus, thermal stability and electrochemical stability of polyimide, we design a novel composite solid polymer electrolyte blending with polyimide fibers framework paper. Polyimide fibers scaffold improves elastic modulus and tensile strength of composite electrolyte film. Effective ion transport network layers in electrolyte system are formed by adding polyimide fibers due to strong interaction between electron-withdrawing atoms and groups in the lithium salt for accelerating the dissociation of the lithium salt. Thus, polyimide composite electrolyte shows higher Li+ transfer number (∼2 times) than pure polyethylene oxide electrolyte, which is beneficial to regulate Li deposition for lithium dendrites inhibition. The electrochemical window of polyimide composite electrolyte is widened to 4.87 V after introducing stable physicochemical fibers framework, leading to high compatibility and stability with lithium metal anode. Therefore, the Li symmetrical battery with polyimide fibers framework composite electrolyte delivers low overpotential and long cycling life at different current densities. And the all-solid-state Li/LiFePO4 battery using this composite electrolyte reveals long cycling life (418 cycles), high Coulomb efficiency (99.97%), high capacity retention of 89.5% at 0.3 C, and good rate performance at 60 °C.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Polyimide fibers framework
Composite polymer electrolyte
Lithium dendrite suppression
All-solid-state battery

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Schematic diagram of synthetic route and microstructure for PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE. (b) The photo of polyimide fibers. (c) The photos and (d) stretching diagram of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE films. (e) The SEM image of PI fibers. (f) The top-view SEM image and (g) the cross-section SEM image of PEO/LiTFSI SPE film. (h) The top-view SEM image and (i) the cross-section SEM image of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE film. (j, k) The EDX mapping images of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE film.

(a) XRD patterns of LiTFSI, PEO, PI fibers, PEO/LiTFSI and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE. (b) The full scan FT-IR spectra of LiTFSI, PEO, PI fibers, PEO/LiTFSI and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE. (c) The FTIR spectra at 1150–1400 cm−1 for PI, LiTFSI and PEO. (d) The detailed FTIR spectra of PEO/LiTFSI and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE between 1150 and 1400 cm−1. (e) Gaussian-Lorentzian fitting of the characteristic absorptions for PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE. (f) Stress–strain plots of PI fibers paper, PEO/LiTFSI and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE.

The DMA plot for (a) PI fibers film, (b) PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE and (c) PEO/LiTFSI SPE film. (d) The DSC curve of PI fibers framework paper. (e) DSC curves of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE, PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO from −60 °C to 90 °C. (f) DSC curves of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE, PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO from −62 °C to −20 °C.

(a, b) The impedance plots of PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE. (c) Ionic conductivity-temperature curves and (d) LSV plots for PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE. (e) The current–time curve and impedance plots of PEO/LiTFSI SPE (e) and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE (f).

Characterization of electrolyte/electrode interface stability and lithium dendrite restrain. (a) Galvanostatic cycling curves of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery and Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| Li battery under 0.05 mA cm−2 at 60 °C. (b, c, d) The details graphic of cycling curves in different time. (e) Galvanostatic cycling curves under 0.1 mA cm−2. (f, g, h) The magnified graphic of cycling curves in different time.

(a) The rate performance of Li/Li symmetrical batteries with PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE under different current densities. (b, c, d) The detailed illustration of the rate cycling curves. The photo images of Li anode of the battery with (e) PI CSPE and (f) PEO/LiTFSI SPE after 10 cycles. The SEM images of lithium metal after cycling in (g) Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery and (h) Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| Li battery after 10 cycles under 0.1 mA cm−2.

(a) Long term cycling performance of all-solid-state lithium metal battery with different CSPE at 0.3C at 60 °C. (b) The polarization of the battery with PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE and PEO/LiTFSI SPE at different cycles. The charge/discharge profiles of the batteries with different CSPE at the first cycle (c) and 50th cycle (d). Rate performance of the battery with PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE for (e) 100 cycles and (f) 475 cycles under various current densities. (g) The charge/discharge plots of PEO/LiTFSI SPE battery at 0.1 C–1C. (h) CV curves of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery at different cycles.

head.ce:title: Polymer nanofibers framework composite solid electrolyte with lithium dendrite suppression for long life all-solid-state lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Material Science & Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory of Engineering Dielectrics and Its Application, Ministry of Education, Harbin University of Science and Technology, Harbin 150080, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Material Science & Chemical Engineering
Key Laboratory of Engineering Dielectrics and Its Application
Harbin University of Science and Technology

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Material Science & Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory of Engineering Dielectrics and Its Application, Ministry of Education, Harbin University of Science and Technology, Harbin 150080, China

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Department of Chemistry, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work and should be considered co-first authors.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The widespread deployment of lithium metal battery is limited by inhomogeneous electrodeposition of lithium metal (the growth of lithium dendrite), leading to pulverization, “dead” lithium and the unrestricted volume expansion of lithium metal anode. Owing to the high elastic modulus, thermal stability and electrochemical stability of polyimide, we design a novel composite solid polymer electrolyte blending with polyimide fibers framework paper. Polyimide fibers scaffold improves elastic modulus and tensile strength of composite electrolyte film. Effective ion transport network layers in electrolyte system are formed by adding polyimide fibers due to strong interaction between electron-withdrawing atoms and groups in the lithium salt for accelerating the dissociation of the lithium salt. Thus, polyimide composite electrolyte shows higher Li+ transfer number (∼2 times) than pure polyethylene oxide electrolyte, which is beneficial to regulate Li deposition for lithium dendrites inhibition. The electrochemical window of polyimide composite electrolyte is widened to 4.87 V after introducing stable physicochemical fibers framework, leading to high compatibility and stability with lithium metal anode. Therefore, the Li symmetrical battery with polyimide fibers framework composite electrolyte delivers low overpotential and long cycling life at different current densities. And the all-solid-state Li/LiFePO4 battery using this composite electrolyte reveals long cycling life (418 cycles), high Coulomb efficiency (99.97%), high capacity retention of 89.5% at 0.3 C, and good rate performance at 60 °C.

ce:section.ce:para: Due to the properties of high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and light weight, lithium metal anode has considered to be ideal candidate for high energy density batteries [1–6]. Nevertheless, the formation and growth of lithium dendrites caused by the side reactions in unstable interface between electrolyte and electrode can lead to the consumption and volume expansion of anode along with the pulverization of lithium [7–9]. In all-solid-state lithium metal battery, the formation of lithium dendrites can be inhibited by high lithium ion conductivity inorganic electrolytes (Li7La3Zr2O12, Li3xLa2/3-xTiO3, Li3/8Sr33/80La1/40Zr1/4Ta3/4O3, etc.). But break and pulverization of friable inorganic electrolytes can give rise to the failure of suppression after a large amount of lithium electrodeposition [10,11]. Solid polymer electrolytes with flexibility, stable physicochemical and good mechanical properties can avoid the leakage and volatilization of electrolytes effectively, and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites in a degree [12–16]. However, the application of solid polymer electrolytes is still inherently limited by unstable solid polymer electrolyte and lithium metal anode interphase caused by continuous chemical/electrochemical side reactions [17,18]. Besides, expanding lithium dendrites in the polymer-based solid electrolyte can cause a series of problems such as part short circuit, overheated and unavoidable volume expansion of lithium anode [19,20]. Hence, designing high performance polymer solid electrolyte for stable the interface between electrolyte and electrode is urgent for the lithium dendrite suppression.

Owing to high flexibility, mass light, ionic conducting and compatibility with lithium metal anode, polyethylene oxide (PEO) has been regarded as a good candidate for preparing solid polymer electrolyte [21,22]. Nevertheless, the lithium ion conducting ability, electrochemical window and mechanical properties of PEO cannot meet the demand for high rate ion transfer in cycling process for batteries, causing the unstable electrolyte/electrode interface leading to the formation and growth of lithium dendrites [23]. Great efforts have been adopted to improve the electrochemical properties and mechanical properties of PEO based solid polymer electrolyte further decreasing the growth of lithium dendrites and other side reactions [24,25]. Generally, copolymerization, crosslinking and blocking with the others polymer materials can enhance the compatibility and segment flexibility of PEO, further facilitating its ion conductivity [26,27]. But these approaches are still restrained by complex manufacturing process and can introduce impurities (initiator, crosslinker, unpolymerized monomer, etc.). In addition, blending inorganic fillers and active ceramic fillers into the host polymer are also efficient methods for improving the physicochemical properties of polymer electrolyte system [28–31]. Nevertheless, the poor compatibility for fillers in the polymer can not be ignored, leading to the fillers separating and aggregation during the cycling process of the batteries [32–34].

Owing to excellent physicochemical stability, electrochemical stability, thermal stability and great designability of structure, polyimides are applied as the host for exchange membrane, battery electrolytes films, insulating films and filtration films [35]. Notably, the various choices of monomer component give polyimides great structural designability and physicochemical characteristic, leading to diverse applications [36,37]. In this work, we design a composite solid polymer electrolyte (CSPE) for PEO and lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonylimide (LiTFSI) based system blending with polyimide fibers paper. PEO serves as the ion conducting phase and polyimide fibers framework serves as filler matrix. Due to the high mechanical strength, thermal stability and physicochemical stability of polyimide fibers framework, the composite electrolyte shows enhanced mechanical properties and electrochemical stability. The lithium ion transference number of polyimide introduced CSPE is 0.265, which is 2.08 times to the pure PEO/LiTFSI solid polymer electrolyte (SPE), as well as the electrochemical window of CSPE is also broadened by blending with polyimide fibers framework paper. Additionally, the CSPE reflects higher elastic modulus and tensile strength than PEO SPE. Benefitting from these enhanced properties, the Li symmetrical batteries with CSPE exhibit long cycling life for more than 450 h at different current densities. The all-solid-state lithium metal batteries using CSPE shows stable electrochemical performance (high specific capacity, capacity retention and rate performance). The mechanism of lithium dendrite inhibition for polyimide fibers framework paper CSPE are also explored and discussed.

The design of polyimide (PI) fibers framework paper, PEO/LiTFSI composite solid polymer electrolyte (PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE) is shown in Fig. 1 a, the PEO/LiTFSI solution are poured in the polyimide fibers framework. Fig. 1b presents the light yellow and soft polyimide fibers membrane. After blending with PEO/LiTFSI, the polyimide fibers composite electrolyte film manifests a freestanding and flexible structure (Fig. 1c). Subsequently, tensile measurement of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE film are conducted (Fig. 1d). Impressively, the film could be stretched to ∼ 20 times without any fracture. Subsequently, scan electron microscopy (SEM) measurements were conducted on PI fibers, PEO/LiTFSI SPE film and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE film, respectively. As shown in Fig. 1e and Fig. S3, the diameter distribution of PI fibers ranges from 500 nm to 700 nm, suggesting the well-distributed microstructure of PI fibers. PEO/LiTFSI SPE film reflects mossy phase separated surface (Fig. 1f) with non-penetrating hole in the cross-section SEM image (Fig. 1g), and the thickness of SPE is about 170 μm. The top-view SEM image (Fig. 1h) of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE reflects a rough and complete surface without any holes. The cross-section SEM images in Fig. 1i show that the thickness of the CSPE film is about 134 μm. In the EDX mapping image of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE in Fig. 1j and k, the elements of F, C, O, S and N disperse well in the polymer electrolyte system, suggesting that the homogeneous cross-linking structure is built by PI fibers.

Generally, the high order crystalline structure of PEO based electrolyte system is detrimental to the ion fast transfer [30]. Therefore, XRD measurements are employed to examine the crystalline properties of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE and other contrast samples (Fig. 2 a). The unconspicuous peak for PI demonstrates a low crystallinity. Evidently, two typical peaks of PEO located at 19.3° and 23.4° diminish gradually in PEO, PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE [32], indicating that the introduction of PI fiber can decrease the degree of crystallinity and enhance segment motility of polymer as well. Characteristic peaks can be found in the LiTFSI salt corresponding to the JCPDS card (No: 01-082-2341) for LiTFSI. The peaks of LiTFSI disappear in the XRD plots of PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE due to good dispersibility and low crystallinity. The characteristic peaks of PI are also found in the spectrum of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE, implying that PI and PEO/LiTFSI matrix are combined together.

Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) tests were performed to explore the interaction among the ion, PI fibers and polymer host. The full spectrum of PEO, LiTFSI, PI, PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE are revealed in Fig. 2b. In the magnified FTIR spectra in Fig. 2c, the peak at 1364.9 cm−1 is corresponded to C-N stretching signal for PI fibers. In Fig. 2d, the peak for C-N stretching shifts to 1365.9 cm−1 for PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE, suggesting that the PI fibers have been dispersed into PEO/LiTFSI mixture. In order to explore the mechanism of the interaction among the components in the electrolyte, the peaks in FTIR spectrum are fitted. The spectrum (Fig. 2e) ranging from 1150 to 1400 cm−1 of PEO/LiTFSI SPE reveals that the peaks at 1187.0, 1240.0, 1293.4 and 1353.9 cm−1 are corresponded to –CF3 asymmetric and –CF3 symmetric stretching, –CH2– twist and –CH2– wagging absorptions, respectively [33]. The peak of –CF3 asymmetric stretching, which comes from TFSI−, shifts to 1189.1 cm−1 in PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE, illustrating that the interaction between PI fibers and the –CF3 group leads to the enhanced dissociation and transfer of LiTFSI [33,34].

Stress–strain plots of PI fibers film, PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PI CSPE in Fig. 2f shows that the tensile strength of PI CSPE is 3.1 MPa, which is high than that of PEO/LiTFSI SPE (2.4 MPa) and PI film (2.1 MPa). In addition, the elongation-at-break of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE is much larger than that of pure PI fibers film. The improvement in the mechanical strength can be attributed to the interactions between heterogeneous dispersion of PI fibers and the PEO system.

The mechanical properties and thermal stability are important for composite solid polymer electrolyte when working at high temperature. Elastic modulus of electrolyte films is tested by dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA). As shown in Fig. 3 a, the storage modulus and loss modulus of PI fibers film is about 3.13 MPa and 0.91 MPa at 60 °C. The DMA curves in Fig. 3b reflects that the storage modulus of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE increases with temperature increasing from 47 to 90 °C, and the loss modulus increases slightly, suggesting a good mechanical property. Differently, the storage modulus and loss modulus of PEO/LiTFSI SPE decrease in a similar tendency as temperature increases (Fig. 3c).

Differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) is used to examine the thermal stability and thermal behavior of solid polymer electrolyte. In the DSC curve of PI fibers in Fig. 3d, there is no melting peak or crystallization peak. The melting temperature (Tm) of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE is 54.8 °C (Fig. 3e), which is lower than that of PEO/LiTFSI SPE (55.3 °C), indicating the easier melt for the composite system. The glass-transition temperatures (Tg) of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE, PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO are −35.8 °C, −36.8 °C and −52.8 °C, respectively (Fig. 3f). The higher Tg for PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE and lower degree of crystallinity than that of PEO/LiTFSI SPE, suggesting the easier segment motility in composite electrolyte.

Ionic conductivity of composite solid polymer electrolyte is calculated via AC impedance. The impedance of PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE both shift to lower degree as the temperature increase gradually from 30 °C to 70 °C (Fig. 4 a and b), indicating a better ionic conductivity at high temperature [38]. The ionic conductivity-temperature curves of PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE are shown in Fig. 4c, PEO/LiTFSI SPE film delivers higher conductivity than PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE. All the conductivity values are summarized in Table S1. Although the ionic conductivity of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE declined due to the addition of non-conducting filler phase (insulated PI) [35], the high level for ionic conductivity could be achieved in solid polymer electrolyte according to previous works [13,15,26,29].

Linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) are carried out to test the electrochemical window of PI composite electrolyte. The LSV plots (−1 V to 8 V) of PEO/LiTFSI SPE and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE are shown in Fig. 4d. The electrochemical window of PEO/LiTFSI SPE is only 2.07 V, which could not meet the demand for high voltage cathode materials. PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE remains stable and small current up to 4.87 V (vs Li+/Li), suggesting that the electrochemical window of composite electrolyte is broadened via adding PI fibers framework.

The lithium ion transference number (tLi+) of composite electrolyte films are checked via chronoamperometry and AC impedance. The polarization curve of the battery with PEO/LiTFSI SPE is shown in Fig. 4e, the polarization voltage is 10 mV. The EIS of the battery using PEO/LiTFSI SPE also decreases after polarization with tLi+ calculated to be 0.127. On the contrary, the EIS of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE increases after polarization, with tLi+ is calculated to be 0.265 according to Eq. (1) in the experimental part of supporting information, demonstrating that the tLi+ is enhanced after adding PI fibers in the composite electrolyte system.

The interface stability between lithium metal anode and solid polymer electrolyte is important for lithium dendrite inhibition during lithium plating and stripping process. The interfacial properties for CSPE toward lithium metal anode are investigated in symmetrical Li| CSPE| Li batteries under the current densities of 0.05 mAcm−2 and 0.1 mAcm−2 at 60 °C. In Fig. 5 a, Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery maintains a lower overpotential for ∼36 mV beyond 450 h. However, the Li| Li cell with PEO/LiTFSI SPE reflects a higher overpotential for about 48 mV at 0.05 mAcm−2. As shown in Fig. 5b, c, d, the detail the curves of the Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery at 25–30 h, 195–199 h, and 191–395 h are smooth, demonstrating the homogenous lithium deposition on the anode through the designed CSPE. As shown in Fig. 5e, when the current density is set up to 0.1 mA cm−2, the overpotential of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li is stabilized at ∼45 mV after standing for 450 h, suggesting stable Li plating/stripping behaviors in the interface between CSPE and lithium anode. However, the comparative Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| Li cell exhibits irregular voltage polarization and suddenly shorts at 363 h, implying a nonuniform Li plating/stripping in the PEO/LiTFSI SPE due to the poor mechanical properties and low lithium ion transfer ability. The detailed galvanostatic cycling curves (25–30 h, 195–199 h, and 191–395 h) of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery in Fig. 5f, g, h reflects lower overpotential than that of Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| Li battery, implying the higher interface stability and compatibility with lithium metal anode. The cycling performance (Fig. S5) of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery at higher current densities (0.2 mA cm−2 and 0.3 mA cm−2) reflects higher electrochemical stability. These results confirm that the PI fibers in the composite system could stable the interface between electrolyte and lithium metal anode, leading to lithium dendrites suppression.

The rate performance of Li symmetrical batteries with PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE and PEO/LiTFSI SPE are tested and displayed in Fig. 6 a. Compared with the overpotential (∼181, 427 and 994 mV) for Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| Li battery, Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery (Li| PI CSPE| Li) exhibits a lower overpotential of ∼38, 85 and 126 mV at 0.05, 0.1 and 0.2 mA cm−2. There is no internal short circuit or rapid drop in overpotential caused by excess formation and growth lithium dendrites during the cycling, demonstrating a stable interface between PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE and lithium anode. Short-circuiting occurs at 87 h for PEO/LiTFSI SPE battery due to the formation and growth of lithium dendrites in the interface of SPE/Li anode [39]. A direct appearance observation of the lithium anode after 10 cycles at 0.1 mA cm−2 are reflected in Fig. 6e and f, where bright and flat surface can be observed for Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery. On the contrary, lithium metal anode from Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| Li battery shows relatively obvious dark and rough surface. As illustrated in Fig. 6g, SEM image of lithium metal sheet for Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| Li battery reveals smooth surface, indicating the effective suppression of Li dendrite growth due to high tensile strength and high lithium ion conductive matrix structures. Nevertheless, the lithium anode for Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| Li battery shows obvious moss-like lithium dendrites, which demonstrates inhomogeneous Li deposition via SPE and the unstable interface between SPE and lithium anode.

The practical applicability of CSPE is assessed in the all-solid-state lithium metal battery with LiFePO4 (LFP) served as active material for cathode (Fig. 7 ). The long-term cycling plots in Fig. 7a exhibits the Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery delivers high discharge capacity of 137.4 mAh g−1 at the 100th cycle and high capacity retention of 89.5% after 418 cycles at 60 °C and 0.3 C. In addition, Coulombic efficiency of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery can be achieved to 99.97 % after long-term cycling. The cycling stability of battery is mainly assigned to desirable and stable interface between PI CSPE and lithium metal anode. Although Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| LFP battery exhibits high capacity of 157.5 mAh g−1, it fails after 68 cycles on account of low Coulombic efficiency due to the uncontrollable growth of lithium dendrites. FT-IR spectrum is employed to analyze the side reaction products in the interface between CSPE and electrode. In Fig. S7d, the peak at 1189.1 cm−1 is corresponded to –CF3 asymmetric stretching for TFSI- in PEO/LiTFSI SPE, which shifts to 1186.8 cm−1 after cycling [33,34]. Tiny shifting from 1187.0 cm−1 to 1187.5 cm−1 for PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE suggest higher stable dissociation and transfer of LiTFSI than that of PEO/LiTFSI SPE after cycling, demonstrating the stable interface between lithium metal and PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE. The polarization potential to cycle number for different batteries is illustrated in Fig. 7b. Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery displays smaller overpotential than that of PEO/LiTFSI SPE battery, which is attributed to the high ionic conductivity and mechanical properties of PI CSPE. Furthermore, the charge–discharge curves at the first and 50th cycle of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery in Fig. 7c, d are smooth and show minimum overpotential without obvious increase after 50 cycles. Nevertheless, overcharge is observed in the capacity and voltage profiles for Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| LFP battery, implying the unstable electrochemical interface between SPE and lithium anode.

The rate performance of all-solid-state lithium metal battery is evaluated at various current densities under 60 °C. As shown in Fig. 7e, Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery exhibits specific capacities of 145.6, 144.1, 142.1 and 139.1 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, 0.3 C, 0.5 C and 1 C, respectively. When the current density returns to 0.2 C, PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE battery deliver a reversible capacity of 141.4 mAh g−1, suggesting the ultrahigh electrochemical rate performance of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery. Whereas, the Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| LFP battery reflects high specific capacities of 160.4 and 148.1 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and 0.3 C. When the current density increases to 0.5 C and 1 C, Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| LFP battery reflects rapidly decreasing capacities of 123.6 and 80.2 mAh g−1, due to low ionic conductivity for PEO/LiTFSI SPE at high current density. Moreover, the battery with PEO/LiTFSI SPE fails after 296 cycles (Fig. 7f), and long-term stable cycling can be achieved by Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery for 475 cycles, demonstrating the enhanced effect of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE for fast ion transfer and in stabilize the interface between CSPE and anode. The mechanism of stabilizing interface with lithium metal anode is described as follows: PI fibers provide a large amount of ion interface transmission channels. Besides, the enhanced elastic modulus at high temperature is beneficial for lithium dendrites inhibition. In Fig. 7g, Li| PEO/LiTFSI SPE| LFP battery shows rapid capacity decay and rapid increase in polarization overpotential with the increase in the current density. The charge/discharge plots of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery in Fig. 7h reveal that the capacity decays a little and the polarization voltage increases slightly with the current densities increasing. These results demonstrate remarkably enhanced rate performance of PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE because high ionic conductivity and chemical stability for lithium dendrites repression. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements are carried out to further identify the reactions in the all-solid-state lithium metal battery. The CV plots of Li| PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE| LFP battery at the scan rate of 0.5 mV s−1 are shown in Fig. 7i, the reduction peak at 3.18 V for the first scan shifts to 3.06 V at the 5th cycle, and the peak area increases with the cycles increasing. This implies that the capacity increases with charge and discharge process, which is consistent with the results of long-term cycling. In addition, the single peak for oxidation and reduction declares that no side reactions occur during cycling.

In this work, the PI fibers with stable physicochemical properties are introduced in the PEO/LiTFSI based solid polymer electrolyte. The electrochemical properties (lithium ion conductivity and electrochemical window) and mechanical properties (tensile strength and elastic modulus) of composite solid polymer electrolyte are enhanced due to adding the high performance PI fibers. Befitting from these enhanced properties, the interface between electrolyte and lithium metal anode are stabilized by the PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE, leading to the inhibition of lithium dendrites. Hence, the Li symmetrical batteries with PI fibers CSPE exhibits long cycling life for 450 h and good rate performance, the pure PEO/LiTFSI SPE battery shows short life and fails for short circuiting and large polarization. Furthermore, the all-solid-state lithium metal battery with PEO/LiTFSI/PI CSPE delivers high specific capacity (137.4 mAh g−1), high capacity retention (89.5%) high Coulomb efficiency (99.97%) for 418 cycles and good rate performance for 475 cycles.

Yuhan Li: Methodology, Validation, Writing – original draft, Funding acquisition. Zhenyu Fu: Investigation, Data curation. Shiyao Lu: Writing – review & editing. Xue Sun: Methodology, Formal analysis. Xiaorui Zhang: Investigation, Conceptualization. Ling Weng: Project administration, Supervision, Resources.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

Yuhan Li, Zhenyu Fu and Shiyao Lu contributed equally to this work and should be considered co-first authors.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Harnessing the volume expansion of MoS3 anode by structure engineering to achieve high performance beyond lithium-based rechargeable batteries
Adv. Mater.
